text: Although appearing only now, this polymorphic character occupies a central role in the novel, being at once a dogkeeper, a hunter, a poet, a painter, and possibly the only fictional author of the entire book.  In a reply to Smith, published in a 1987 article, Sokolov himself stated that: "the verse chapters are written by Iakov. He has nothing to do with me, but he has to be and is 'sophisticated', because he is that same painter who is discussed in the prose chapters (not the ones from Il'ia) 'The Hunter's Tale', where he is the youth living in his mother's house; the boy in love with the simple-minded girl whom the sailors take under the boat; the sketcher, the author of the Self-Portrait in Uniform and so forth; (And, of course, here, in this chapter, he is the hunter and poet who is “not fresh and not young”); 'The Hunter's Tale, or Pictures from an Exhibition', where he is Iakov Il'ich Palamakhterov, 'the incorruptible witness who is journeying towards the end of his practical and pitiless time,' and imagines the scene from nineteenth-century ethnography in which his greatgrandfather takes part; 'Pictures from an Exhibition' (9), where he observes street scenes from the window of a cadet school; see also the other similar parts of the book, 13 and 16. They are written (all of them) from the point of view of an author, but that of a stylized author, i.e., once again, not directly from myself. Iakov is a poet, a painter, a dreamer, a member of the intelligentsia, who was born and grew up in the city. He is already grown up when he comes to the Itil” (327). Yakov plays a central role also in the structuring of the plot, as it is him who kills Ilya in revenge.

Johnson noted: "Yakov is Ilya's son – to whatever extent anything is anything in the twilight world between dog and wolf. Both Yakov and Ilya remain unaware of this, however, and when their later lives as grinder and dogkeeper finally and fatally cross, they are equally unaware of their transient friendship in the hospital (...). [Yakov is] re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus. He unwittingly both kills his father and (albeit not literally) 'marries' a version of his mother.
